>From: Derek James <djames@...>
>
>The point is, there is no direct bias against network size or
>efficiency.  So no, there is currently no bias *against* neutral
>mutations.  That's what I believe Colin and Ken are arguing for, the
>allowance for a lot of structure that's neither directly helping or
>hurting fitness in the present, but that may be coopted later in the
>run to increase fitness.
>
>If you want to see this in action, just run NEAT on a very simple
>problem and crank up the mutation rates.  It will still solve the
>problem, but you will have networks that are much larger than they
>really need to be.

Ah...I see.  Well, isn't the solution to that to change the fitness 
function?

Give each network both a 'fitness' and a 'complexity' ranking.  When 
deciding on the ranking of specimens, sort first on fitness, descending, and 
then on complexity, ascending.  Thus, if two networks have the same fitness, 
the smaller one wins.

If the fitness function was very granular, like to 10 decimal places, it's 
unlikely that the complexity factor would ever come into play.  But if you 
round the fitness (or scale it), then two networks that are 'close' to one 
another would then be folded into 'the same' and the smaller one wins.  And 
you could make that 'scaling' be dynamic...like 10% of the range between 
average and best within a species.  If the average fitness is 10, the best 
is 12, then the range between average and best is 2.  10% of that is 0.2.  
So, any two that are within 0.2 of each other would (kinda) get the same 
fitness score.  And that percentage could be a tunable parameter so we can 
find the best range for where an 'advantage' is a CLEAR advantage and is 
more important than complexity.

This does mean that if a mutation adds complexity without adding a clear 
advantage, that one is selected against.  However, that's not entirely fair. 
  So...instead of only keeping ONE 'elite' member, have a minimum of 2 but 
calculated at 10% (or so) of the offspring for the species.  That allows 
those good but not clearly so networks to survive long enough to try and get 
better before being pruned back out.

What do you think?  Think that would do the trick?
